SourceString: The Aegis is the shield of Athena, Greek goddess of battle.
Hephaistos is the divine smith of Olympos. His anvil is the heart of his creations.
Archimedes was one of the greatest of Greece\'s philosophers and scientists.
Artemis, the Greek goddess of the hunt, is renowned for her skill with the bow.
A renowned huntress, Atalanta accompanied the Argonauts in their search for the Golden Fleece.
After the war with the gods, the titan Atlas was condemned to bear the heavens upon his shoulders for all eternity.
Thanatos, the incarnation of death, carries a sword with the power to rend the very souls of mere mortals.
Apollo is the god of light and the twin brother of Artemis whose skill with the bow is matched only by his sister.
Charon is the ferryman of the underworld, guiding souls across the river Styx to their final rest. His obol is his symbol, a coin that ensures safe passage for those who pay the price.

In the deepest pits of the underworld lies Tartaros. Cold as the grave and swathed in darkness, it is here that punishment is meted out for those mortals foolish enough to oppose the will of the gods.
Circe, the daughter of Helios, is a powerful enchantress who transforms her enemies through the use of potions and herbs and her magic wand.
Polyphemus is the one-eyed giant son of Poseidon, feared for his immense strength. His club is his weapon and symbol, capable of crushing anything in its path.
Theseus, slayer of the Minotaur, embodies courage that inspires mortals and gods alike.
Although not as strong or swift as the other heroes of legend, Odysseus\' formidable guile made him a match for any foe.
Demeter, goddess of growth and fertility, turns the world to winter in her sorrow. Her duality reflects both nurturing abundance and the grief that she endures.
Eos is the goddess and personification of the dawn, who rose each morning from her home at the edge of the river Oceanus to deliver light and disperse the night.
The drink of Dionysos, Greek god of wine and revelry, is a potent brew indeed.
Eris is the goddess of discord and chaos, who delights in conflict among gods and mortals alike. Her Strife is her weapon and symbol, sowing quarrels wherever it touches.
Essence of Eternal Rose of Aphrodite
Embodiment of Eternal Rose of Aphrodite
Incarnation of Eternal Rose of Aphrodite
Aphrodite’s eternal rose glows with a beauty beyond mortal grasp. It is the emblem of her endless love and passion.
A gentle nymph who was unfairly turned into a monster, Skylla became a creature of pure rage and hunger.
Gaia is the primal goddess of the earth, and the mother of Typhon and Ouranos. Her blessing brings life and fertility to all living things.
The Golden Fleece, sought after by Jason and his Argonauts, is rumored to hold great power as well as great beauty.
Essence of Hades\' Helm of Darkness
Embodiment of Hades\' Helm of Darkness
Incarnation of Hades\' Helm of Darkness

Hades is the god of the underworld, ruler of the dead. The Helm of Darkness grants him the power to move unseen among gods and mortals alike, and is the mark of his dominion over the shadows and the unseen.
Hekate is a mysterious Greek goddess associated with the moon, childbirth, and magic.
The Sun Crown of Helios is a symbol of his authority over the skies. Its golden rays reflect his strength, vitality, and the endless cycle of day.
The queen of the gods of Olympos. Her scepter is a mark of sovereignty and divine majesty.
Herakles was the strongest of all the Greek heroes.
Hermes the Messenger is the swiftest of the Greek gods. He is known for his iconic winged sandals.
Hestia, goddess of the hearth and the home, grants warmth and peace to gods and mortals alike.
Hippolyta is the daughter of Ares and queen of the Amazons who wears her father’s war belt proudly.
A divine Corinthian hero, Bellerophon was known for slaying the Chimera and capturing and taming the winged horse Pegasus.
Hypnos is the personification of sleep and the fatherless son of Nyx. His calm is his power and symbol, lulling the world into peaceful slumber.
Moros, brother to Thanatos and the Fates, is the personification of impending doom.
Essence of Iron Will of Ajax
Embodiment of Iron Will of Ajax
Incarnation of Iron Will of Ajax
Numbered among the greatest of the heroes of the Trojan war, Ajax was known not only for the strength of his arm, but even more for his indomitable spirit.
Minos, son of Zeus and king of Crete, was famed for his wisdom and rule. In death, he became a judge of souls.
The sickle of Kronos is the instrument of the Titan’s will. Through it, he commands time, mortality, and the fate of the world.
From the slaying of the Gorgon, Medusa to the saving of kingdoms, Perseus left behind a legacy greater than kings.
Medea is a princess and sorceress of Colchis, known for her skill in potion-making. She aided Jason in his search for the Golden Fleece.
Pandora was the first mortal woman, crafted by Hephaistos by the order of Zeus. Her box is her weapon and symbol, holding both calamity and the faint hope that remains for mankind.
Persephone, favored daughter of the earth goddess Demeter, was forced into marriage with Hades. She now shares rule of the underworld, yet it brings her only sorrow.
The Cyclopes who crafted Zeus\' Thunderbolt also gifted his brother with a magical trident.
Prometheus, son of the titan Iapetus, gave the gift of fire to mankind.
Ares, the Greek god of war, is venerated and feared in equal measure. He is cruel, vengeful, and nearly mad - only a fool would risk his wrath.
Nemesis is the goddess of divine retribution who believes swift and inescapable punishment is the only way to uphold justice, and justice is the only way to stop the world from falling into ruin.
Essence of Rheia’s Gift of Life
Embodiment of Rheia’s Gift of Life
Incarnation of Rheia’s Gift of Life
Rheia, mother of gods and guardian of life, watches over her children with pride. Her gift ensures their power endures and the world blooms in their hands.
Selene is the goddess of the moon, who rides across the night sky. Her moonlight is a symbol of her serenity and her gift to the world.
Hector, prince of Troy, was renowned for his noble spirit and steadfast nature. He fell defending his homeland, mourned even by his enemies.

Orpheus was a legendary musician and poet who descended into the underworld to recover his lost wife Eurydice, but failed. Eventually, Hephaistos took pity on the unlucky lovers and elevated them to join him on Olympos.
Theia, Titaness of sight and vision. Her brilliance brings clarity and radiance to the cosmos.
Born as a chaotic force to challenge the Olympian gods, Typhon was one of the most terrifying and destructive of all creatures, until he was slain by a nameless hero.
Achilles was the greatest of all the Greek warriors of the Trojan War. His strength and speed in battle were legendary.
Narcissus, whose beauty was unmatched among mortals, became obsessed with himself. His vanity was both his pride and his curse.
Chiron is the wisest of the centaurs, teacher of heroes and healer of wounds. His wisdom is his symbol, guiding mortals and gods alike with insight and patience.
Zeus is the mightiest of the gods of Olympos. The thunderbolt is his weapon and symbol.
